bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Gustaf E. Lambert, February 25, 1950

div1.p: Truby explains to Lambert the conditions for being placed on the Roll of Honor. Truby says that Ames does not meet these conditions, although he did take good care of the yellow fever volunteers.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Gustaf E. Lambert, February 25, 1950
div1.opener:
Copy for
Dr Hench
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
February 25, 1950
Mr. Gus E. Lambert
121 Morris Blvd.
Birmingham, Alabama
Dear Lambert:
div1.p:
Your recent letter is here and because of the fact that you do not
seem to have a clear understanding of my feelings of respect and
admiration for our late friend and associate, Dr. Roger Post Ames,
I will try to enlighten you although, if you will carefully read
my book on the Yellow Fever Episode, you will find that I praised
Ames and his professional work most highly. In fact, I think I
said more about his fine achievements at Columbia Barracks, especial-
ly in his treatment of yellow fever, than has ever been published
elsewhere. Dr. Ames and I were very close friends, as you must
know, and on that account alone I would do everything possible to
honor his memory.

Congress very carefully drew up the provisions of the Roll of Honor
Act, approved February 28, 1929, and the men that were to be so
honored were selected and classified under two heads; first, the
Board consisting of Reed, Carol, Agramonte, and Lazear; and second,
all of the men who underwent at least one of the Board's tests at
Camp Lazear. To make it ironclad, Congress even designated the
actual names of the four members of the Board and the names of the
men who took the test. This was evidently done so that the many
officers and men at our hospital at Columbia Barracks in Cuba, who
were also most helpful to the Board, could not be added to the list
later and thereby lessen the great value of this precious medal to
the real heroes. You know very well that since this Act was passed
many bills have repeatedly been introduced into Congress to place
other names on that list. None of them have been favorably consid-
ered.

Dr. Hench advised you correctly that General Orders No. 83, dated
Nov. 14, 1900, did not make Dr. Ames a member of that Board. That
was a local order of our Department Commander, General Lee, which
placed doctors and men from our hospital at Major Reed's disposal
to help perform the routine duties at Camp Lazear. You will also
notice that two enlisted men of our detachment, John S. Morris and
John R. Kissinger, were also ordered to report to Major Reed for
duty in that same order. They were not members of the Board however
as that was created by orders from the War Department and to change
the membership of the Board would require orders from that same
source. Kissinger took the mosquito test and his name was included
in the Act of Congress, mentioned above. Private Morris worked at
the Camp but did not take any of the tests and was not a member of
the Board so he is not included as one of the heroes. Dr. Ames was
Mr. Gus E. Lambert
- 2 -
probably needed by Major Reed at Camp Lazear for several reasons
but one of the main ones, I am sure, was to have him present in
Camp whenever any of the men who had been bitten by infected
mosquitoes developed any symptoms that might turn out to be yellow
fever. As Dr. Ames was to take care of Reed's cases at the yellow
fever hospital, I feel sure that Ames indicated to Major Reed that
it was most important that he should be at Camp Lazear part of the
time every day in order to diagnose every cases at the earliest
possible moment. This, of course was one of the most important
things in the treatment which brought such great success to Ames.
General Order No. 83 was probably considered necessary since Dr. Ames
had to do part-time duty in two places and under two commanders. At
the yellow fever hospital, Stark was in command while Camp Lazear
was commanded by Reed. The duties of Dr. Ames, however, were strict-
ly professional in both places and strictly in accordance with his
contract with the Government -- i.e., to treat the sick, and because
of his extensive experience with yellow fever, to assist in every
way possible in the care of such cases. He did that work in a
highly efficient manner.

The Act of Congress honored the members of the Board for “ the
brilliant character of this scientific achievement” and also honored
the men who underwent the hazardous tests at Camp Lazear. Dr. Ames
belonged to neither of these groups, therefore was not qualified to
receive the medal under the terms of the Act.

The conclusion I drew of this matter as published in my book, “The
Yellow Fever Episode”, are on pages 191 and 192. That can not be
changed.

The very fine precepts of Masonry which you mention could in no way
be violated when a commissioned officer obeys his oath of office and
supports the laws and regulations on such matters as this. Further-
more, I do not agree with you that Dr. Ames was deliberately harmed
in any way by the Congressional Act. In fact, his achievements in
caring for the sick of that Board have brought him most signal honors
as a doctor.

In view of the lack of a substantial marking at the grave of our
lamented friend and other matters you mentioned, why not get some of
his old friends in New Orleans and other places to make an effort
to bring this neglect to the attention of the medical profession in
New Orleans and to the public in general? In this connection, I
received a letter from Dr. W. M. Brumby of Houston, Texas about a
year ago:

"I am writing an account of my contacts with my close friend
since boyhood, a classmate at Tulane University, Roger Post Ames
to place in the Medical Library at Tulane.

“I have read with interest your ‘Memoir of Walter Reed’ and,
because they run a close parallel with facts I have at hand,
collected over the past fifty years, I should like to use, and
Mr. Gus E. Lambert
- 3 -
credit to you some passages from your work that give mention of
Dr. Ames.”

I am sure that Dr. Brumby would join heartily with anyone who proposed
a memorial to Ames at Tulane University similar to that which honored
Lazear at Washington and Jefferson University. You will remember that
Dr. Hench delivered the address a few years ago and paid a very fine
tribute to Lazear's memory when a new building was dedicated to him at
that school.

Certainly, Tulane University can well be proud of the fine profession-
al attainments of their former student, Dr. Ames.

As I left Columbia Barracks November 30, 1900, I have no personal
knowledge of the work you said that Ames and others did in placing
infected mosquitoes on volunteers. My information about that is
entirely hearsay.

In regard to Dr. Mazzuri, I am glad that you have finally found out
who assisted Ames at the yellow fever hospital during the last few
cases from Camp Lazear. Heretofore, you insisted that it was Dr. Pinto
who treated the cases when Dr. Ames was not present and Andrus was
having so much trouble. I did not know Mazzuri. He came to Columbia
Barracks after I left.
Thank you for the pictures you sent. I was quite interested in them.
